availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Laban Thomas Moore (Representative and Lawrence Co attorney)

body.p: A Kentucky attorney, politician, and soldier. Attended Marshall Academy and graduated from Marietta College. Studied law at Transylvania University. Admitted to the bar in 1849. Practiced law in Mount Sterling, Kentucky, Louisa, Kentucky and Catlettsburg, Kentucky. Married to Sarah A. Everett Moore. Father of Fellecia E. Moore, Mary F. Moore, S. G. Moore, Minnie H. Moore, and Drusy Moore. Member of the Whig Party and Democratic Party. Served the Ninth Congressional District of Kentucky as an Opposition Party member of the United States House of Representative from 1859 to 1861. Served as a colonel in the 14th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment from November 1861 to January 1862. Moved to Catlettsburg, Kentucky to practice law.

bibl.p: Biographical Directory of the United States Congress, s.v. “Moore, Laban Theodore,” (http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000907) (accessed December 20, 2016); Charles Lanman, Biographical Annals of the Civil Government of the United States (Washington: J. M. Morrison, 1887), 350; “Laban Theodore Moore,” (http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7773434) (accessed December 20, 2016); “Col. Laban T. Moore Dead,” Mt. Sterling Advocate (Mount Sterling, Ky.), November 15, 1892; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Lawrence County, The Town of Louisa, p. 186; Tenth Manuscript Census of the United States (1880), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Boyd County, Upper Catlettsburg Precinct 6, p. 17.
